title: No winners in police merger impasse |
text:
T he city and the county now have an opportunity to act like adults and put their final stamp of approval on the proposed Savannah-Chatham County police merger.
Like two squabbling school kids, Savannah city aldermen and the Chatham County commissioners can’t strike a deal on a new police merger agreement, and each blames the other side for the failure.
Chatham County Commission Chairman Al Scott says the version of the agreement passed this summer by the council was not in keeping with a framework both government bodies had approved in May as a basis for the formal agreement. That framework established the county’s shared cost at about $14.2 million, in addition to requiring approval by both bodies before additional expenses are made.
The major sticking point was the city adding language that commits the county to share in the $2.8 million in pay increases approved by the council. The city wants the county to share about 24 percent of the cost of the pay increases.
When the agreement went before the county commission last month, the pay increase language was stripped out of the proposed agreement and sent back to the City Council.
In a letter to Scott this week, Mayor Edna Jackson said she found the removal of the language regarding the salary increases “troubling.” She said the city manager had tried to schedule a policy committee meeting before the pay changes were implemented, but the county rejected her requests.
“City Council has clearly demonstrated its commitment to public safety by fully supporting critical pay scale increases,” she said. “I will not recommend that the City Manager bring the County’s version of the agreement before City Council until we receive a definitive answer from the County on this matter of great importance.”
Scott has already offered a definitive answer from the county by removing the language committing the county to chip in for the pay raises. In fact when the pay raises were announced, Jackson said the city would pay the costs if the county didn’t chip in.
For his part, Scott supports the pay increases. He even suggests they aren’t high enough. “In fact, I don’t know if the proposed salaries are adequate to retain and recruit the best officers,” Scott said this week. “But that is a discussion for a future policy committee meeting.”
And there’s the rub — the police policy committee. In a letter to Scott dated Sept. 28, Jackson requested the pay increases be considered by the committee, which comprises her, Scott and the city and county managers.
In his response, dated Sept. 29, Scott replied that he wanted to wait until the merger agreement is approved before the police policy committee considers the issue.
But there was a truce during Thursday’s council workshop. Scott was invited to the workshop and repeated his argument that the police pay raises approved by the council need to go before the police policy committee before the commission considers offering financial support toward the associated costs.
“I think it carries more weight,” Scott said. “It carries more strength.”
After Scott addressed some questions from council members, Jackson said that a policy committee meeting would be scheduled for next week.
While some commissioners who have taken a strong stance against the merger may vote in opposition, Scott said he thought the increases, which he expected to cost the county about $493,000, would be supported by most of the commissioners at the committee’s recommendation.
“On the county’s side it’s not a lot of money,” he said.
The committee meeting is a good first step. If the panel does meet and recommends the pay raises already approved by the council, then months of finger-pointing and debating will end, unless the county finds something to nit-pick.
This agreement is too important to let process supersede common sense. City and county taxpayers deserve to know the costs of policing.
This isn’t an “I win—you lose” situation. Unless the city and county come up with a pathway to an agreement, it’s a “lose-lose” situation for all Chatham County residents, including those who live in the city.
We’ll be watching next week to see if the police policy committee does meet and if the commission will once again vote on the merger agreement at next Friday’s commission meeting.
